newsitem.title: IRAQ: Turkish troops press anti-PKK campaign in Iraq.
newsitem.headline: Turkish troops press anti-PKK campaign in Iraq.

text.p: Several thousand Turkish troops, backed by tanks and heavy artillery, pushed across the border into northern Iraq early on Wednesday in a move against separatist Kurdish rebel bases.

Witnesses said the assault, which began at 3 a.m. (2300 GMT) followed a security sweep by local Iraqi Kurdish authorities, who ordered all journalists to leave the border region and confiscated mobile telephones capable of reaching Turkey.
"Three thousand troops, including tanks and artillery, started crossing at 2300 GMT and they are still continuing," a resident close to the border said.
Other witnesses said troops later headed northeast away from Zakho.

A Turkish Foreign Ministry spokesman said the operation was a "limited" one, in coordination with local Iraqi Kurds, to oust separatist guerrillas of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) from the border marshes.
However, a senior security source told Reuters: "This is a wide and comprehensive operation."
There were no immediate signs of any clashes along the border areas of Iraq, scene in the past of bloody firefights between Turkish security forces and PKK guerrillas.
Turkish army officers inside Iraq were tight-lipped, with one saying only: "We are here on exercises."
"Some of our troops entered the region...in the region of Zakho," Foreign Ministry spokesman Sermet Atacanli told a news briefing in the Turkish capital Ankara.
"(Iraqi Kurdish leader Massoud) Barzani began an operation against the PKK this morning, our troops have been going into northern Iraq to support this operation."
He said Turkish participation against the PKK, at the invitation of Barzani, was "limited" but that troops would take part in clashes as necessary.
Residents on the Turkish side said the border crossing at Habur was closed to all civilian traffic.
"There is a news blackout. No member of the press is permitted access to Zakho," a local Iraqi Kurdish official said.
Turkish soliders later enforced the news blackout, barring reporters from returning to the area.
Local authorities confiscated the film of a Western photographer who provides pictures to Reuters and other news agencies, before ordering him out of the area.
The Iraqi side of the border is under the general control of Barzani's KDP, a rival of the separatist PKK fighting for independence or autonomy in southeast Turkey.
Last year, Barzani teamed up with the forces of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein against rival Iraqi Kurdish leader Jalal Talabani, prompting U.S. missile strikes against Iraqi targets.

Turkish troops regularly cross back and forth in "hot pursuit" of the PKK. In March 1995, tens of thousands of troops pushed deep into Iraq for a prolonged campaign that drove the PKK back but failed to crush them.
A KDP representative in the southeastern Turkish city of Diyarbakir said Turkish jets flew bombing missions from a base in the city.
"Turkish planes have been bombing PKK (Kurdistan Workers Party) camps in northern Iraq," Haci Salih Huseyin, Diyarbakir representative of the KDP, told reporters.
"They bombed the Zab camp and Hakurk."
Turkish jets have recently stepped up routine cross-border bombings into northern Iraq, according to reports from the region.
